text.0: now all my other friends are here assembled my sireinlaw alone hath not come hither.
text.1: so might he eat the grain and drink the soma and satisfied return unto his dwelling.
text.2: loud belloweth the bull whose horns are sharpened upon the height above earths breadth he standeth.
text.3: that man i guard and save in all his troubles who fills my flanks when he hath shed the soma.
text.4: men with the stone press out for thee o indra strong gladdening soma and thereof thou drinkest.
text.5: bulls they dress for thee and of these thou eatest when maghavan with food thou art invited.
text.6: resolve for me o singer this my riddle the rivers send their swelling water backward.
text.7: the fox steals up to the approaching lion the jackal drives the wildboar from the brushwood.
text.8: how shall i solve this riddle i the simple declare the thought of thee the wise and mighty.
text.9: tell us well knowing as befits the season whitherward is thy prosperous car advancing.
text.10: thus do they magnify me me the mighty higher than even high heaven is my carpole.
text.11: i all at once demolish many thousands my sire begot me with no foe to match me.
text.12: yea and the gods have known me also indra as mighty fierce and strong in every exploit.
text.13: exulting with the bolt i slaughtered vṛtra and for the offerer oped with might the cowstall.
text.14: the deities approached they carried axes splitting the wood they came with their attendants.
text.15: they laid good timber in the firereceivers and burnt the grass up where they found it growing.
text.16: the hare hath swallowed up the opposing razor i sundered with a clod the distant mountain.
text.17: the great will i make subject to the little the calf shall wax in strength and cat the bullock.
text.18: there hath the strongwinged eagle left his talon as a snared lion leaves the trap that caught him.
text.19: even the wild steer in his thirst is captured the leather strap still holds his foot entangled.
text.20: so may the leather strap their foot entangle who fatten on the viands of the brahman.
text.21: they all devour the bulls set free to wander while they themselves destroy their bodies vigour.
text.22: they were well occupied with holy duties who sped in person with their lauds to soma.
text.23: speaking like man mete to us wealth and booty in heaven thou hast the name and fame of hero.
